document.topic_text: Gunnar Bentz amazed at attention Gold medal has brought 11Alive interviews UGA gold medalist Gunnar Bentz Alec McQuade, WXIA 3:16 PM. EDT August 11, 2016 Jul 11, 2016; Chamblee, GA, USA; Gunnar Bentz during practice at Dynamo Swim Club. Mandatory Credit: Kevin D. Liles-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: Kevin D. Liles, Kevin D. Liles) RIO DE JANEIRO -- Gunnar Bentz is a Gold medal winner. "I haven't heard that yet, but that sounds cool," he said. Bentz won his first Olympic Gold medal as a member of the men's 4x100-meter freestyle relay team. He did not swim in the final, but he did swam in the preliminary qualifying heat putting the U.S. in a prime position to win the Gold. Thus, he gets a medal, too. "I haven't even seen it. But I've touched others and they're pretty cool. They're actually pretty heavy," he said. "Just seeing all the work pay off is really great. Being there to cheer on the finals relay to the Gold medal was incredible," he said. Bentz, 20, trained and swam with American stars Ryan Lochte and Michael Phelps who were both part of the relay team. He said spending so much time with them has made him close with the sport's biggest stars. It has also given him a glimpse of the spotlight they are constantly in. "That's a little different than at a swim meet at UGA," he said. "This is beyond anything I've ever seen. We're not in the limelight that often, but to be (in it) here is amazing." Better get used to it, Bentz. Billboards around Atlanta with Bentz and his teammates who have won medals in Rio have surfaced around Atlanta congratulating the Bulldogs. All that attention amazes Bentz, but now that his run at the 2016 Olympics is over, he's has his sights on the next Olympics: The 2020 games in Tokyo. He's already getting to work.
